... (main Event)

The main event in the given post is the individual's paranoia and fear of being hurt or forced into unwanted sexual situations by their friends. The event is described as an ongoing experience that has caused the individual to distrust themselves and others, leading to the severing of relationships with most of their friends.
Post:
"I've lost all my friends because I can't trust anyone. Every time we hang out, I feel like they're just waiting for the perfect moment to hurt me or take advantage of me. It's like they're all just pretending to be my friends, but really, they're just waiting for their chance to strike. I've been burned too many times in the past, and now I can't even stand the thought of being around people. They're all just a bunch of snakes, waiting to pounce on me at any moment."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the individual's isolation and distrust to their own perceived vulnerability and the supposed malicious intentions of others. The individual sees themselves as being inherently weak and vulnerable, and therefore, they believe that others are always plotting against them. This attributional style is stable because it is a long-lasting belief that is not easily changed by external factors or evidence to the contrary.

Event:
Depression, suicidal thoughts, alcohol abuse

Explanation: The post describes the author's experiences with depression, which comes in waves and is characterized by negative thoughts and feelings of hopelessness. The author also mentions that during these low periods, they have suicidal thoughts and tendencies to act out in mean ways towards others. They mention that they drink more when depressed, but when not depressed, they drink moderately. The post also touches on the stigma and shame associated with mental health issues, with the author expressing feelings of isolation and embarrassment.
Post:
"I'm just naturally prone to negative thoughts and feelings of hopelessness. When I'm depressed, I can't help but have suicidal thoughts and act out in hurtful ways towards others. I also tend to drink more when I'm feeling down, but when I'm not depressed, I can control my alcohol consumption."

This post attributes the author's experiences with depression, suicidal thoughts, and alcohol abuse to their inherent nature or personality, implying that these are chronic and stable traits. It also suggests that the author may feel embarrassed or isolated due to societal stigma surrounding mental health issues.
